I use an eBike to commute 2.5 miles to work most days. It is faster than driving and parking, and much cheaper than Uber/Lyft.

A few details

Uber/Lyft costs $12 each way, so $5/mile
Uber/Lyft takes 20 minutes: 10 minutes to arrive, and 10 minute drive
Driving+parking is about 15-20 minutes, depends
Driven by my wife costs too many brownie points
eBike takes 12 minutes (20mph max), no parking hassle (park inside)

title: Something Strange Is Happening in the Fermi Bubbles

last_post.content:
Another cool thing: they seem to have detected some neutrinos emanating from the Fermi bubbles! These neutrinos have energies between 18 and 1,000 TeV. That's ENERGETIC! Our best particle accelerator, the Large Hadron Collider, collides protons with an energy of about 14 TeV. This suggests that the Fermi bubbles contain a lot of very high-energy protons - so-called 'cosmic rays' - which occasionally collide.

https://www.space.com/fermi-bubbles-milky-way-radiation-mystery.html

Large #OpenSSL security release: 1 High and 7 Moderate.

The High (CVE-2023-0286) is memory disclosure due to an ASN1 type confusion. It requires the application to verify CRLs, and the attacker needs to control certificate chain and CRL (but they don't need to be signed).

One Moderate (CVE-2022-4304) is a Bleichenbacher timing oracle against RSA decryption. Cross-network, all padding modes (!), and affects the legacy RSA kex in TLS.

The rest look like crashes.

https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20230207.txt

title: An important next step on our AI journey

last_post.content:
Google used to take pride in minimizing time we spent there, guiding us to relevant pages as quickly as possible. Over time, they tried to answer everything themselves: longer snippets, inline FAQs, search results full of knowledge panels.

Today's Bard announcement feels like their natural evolution: extracting all value out of the internet for themselves, burying pages at the bottom of each GPT-generated essay like footnotes. https://blog.google/technology/ai/bard-google-ai-search-updates/

Visually debugging a Skip List[1] data structure with #GraphViz:
Received a bug report[2] earlier about keys not always reflecting their updated values. Debugging this interactively in the Node REPL (or debugger) is a bit of a nightmare, since the data structure is randomized and uses 4-way links (linked lists) between its nodes on different "express lanes". For these cases I'm often reaching for https://graphviz.org and https://thi.ng/dot to write a few lines of code to quickly visualize key aspects of the data structure I'm fighting with, and doing so helped me find/see the bug within seconds (+ max. 15 mins to write the actual traversal code for building the viz)...

Other than for debugging purposes, I'm also regularly using this approach to document/visualize reactive dataflow topologies created via https://thi.ng/rstream and its many support packages. Some more examples attached (see alt text for details)

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skip_list
[2] https://github.com/thi-ng/umbrella/issues/375#issuecomment-1420799864

#TypeScript #DataViz

title: Complex Berry phase and imperfect non-Hermitian phase transitions

last_post.content:
Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02114 by Longhi & Feng. Authors consider periodically and slowly cycled non-Hermitian models possessing
instantaneous PT symmetry; phase transition can remain exact or become imperfect when the strength of non-Hermiticity in the system is increased above a critical value. Behavior of latter ascribable to a non-vanishing imaginary part of the complex Berry phase associated to the cyclic adiabatic evolution of the system. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2302_02114

StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

I spent an intellectually, socially, and metabolically intense three days at @transmediale last week.

The most fascinating new knowledge tidbit I learned was how the Europeans in the early 19th century discovered that storks migrate to Africa during the winter (rather than to the moon or under water). This was in the talk of Heba Y. Amin.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pfeilstorch

The most interesting artwork was @jmoll Joana Moll's "Silent Opera", an augmented reality work where one walks down the landing strip of the former tempelhofer airport. Using a GPS-enabled mobile phone, the strip turned into a timeline, starting in 1900, tracking the build-up of anthropogenic mass up to the point in 2020, when the sum of human-produced stuff became larger than the entire biomass.

The landing strip is some two kilometers long, so the trip is about 20 minutes up or down the timescale, leaving plenty of time to try to get an embodied understanding of this process as well as speculating what this threshold might mean.

https://janavirgin.com/OPERA/

The amount of information on the timeline is relatively limited. It operates mostly on associative stimulating various directions of my thinking as I walked down the concrete strip. Additionally, the website contains the research that underlies this work, for all who want to dig deeper. I think such a combination of artistic and scientific research formats is quite powerful.

title: Why the world isn't as bad as you think

last_post.content: The news has an "event bias," which causes the media to systematically disregard good news stories that are based on long-term trends rather than daily events.
